skill.name: datacommons-client
skill.description: Work with Data Commons, a platform providing programmatic access to public statistical data from global sources. Use this skill when working with demographic data, economic indicators, health statistics, environmental data, or any public datasets available through Data Commons. Applicable for querying population statistics, GDP figures, unemployment rates, disease prevalence, geographic entity resolution, and exploring relationships between statistical entities.
skill.summary: Work with Data Commons, a platform providing programmatic access to public statistical data from glo...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files and JSON configuration. Shows legitimate API usage examples for Data Commons Python client. No executable scripts, obfuscated code, or persistence mechanisms detected.

low_findings.title: Examples perform Data Commons API calls
low_findings.description: Example code shows "client = DataCommonsClient()" and "response = client.observation.fetch(...)". These calls send queries to datacommons.org API - expected behavior for data integration skill.

low_findings.title: Example writes results to local CSV
low_findings.description: Documentation shows "comparison.to_csv('ca_cities_comparison.csv')". This writes exported data to disk - legitimate use for data analysis workflows.

low_findings.title: Example sets API key via environment
low_findings.description: Setup instructions show "export DC_API_KEY=\"your_api_key_here\"". Standard pattern for API authentication using environment variables.

content.user_title: Query public statistics from Data Commons
content.value_statement: Public statistics are scattered across many sources. This skill provides workflows to resolve places, query demographic and economic data, and explore the Data Commons knowledge graph.
actual_capabilities: Resolve place names to DCIDs with optional type filtering
Resolve coordinates or Wikidata IDs to Data Commons DCIDs
Fetch latest or complete time series observations for statistical variables
Query place hierarchies using relation expressions
Retrieve entity names and property labels from the knowledge graph
Filter observation results by facet domains for source consistency
limitations: Requires an API key from apikeys.datacommons.org for datacommons.org access
Resolve endpoint supports place entities only (countries, states, cities)
Data availability varies by entity and facet source
Must install datacommons-client Python package separately

use_cases.title: Compare state metrics
use_cases.description: Compare population, income, and unemployment across multiple states using consistent data sources.

use_cases.title: Build time series datasets
use_cases.description: Retrieve historical data for a variable across multiple years for trend analysis and visualization.

use_cases.title: Resolve places at scale
use_cases.description: Batch resolve place names to DCIDs before integrating with downstream data pipelines.

prompt_templates.title: Get latest population
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginner query for a few places
prompt_templates.prompt: Resolve California and Texas to DCIDs using the Resolve API, then fetch the latest Count_Person values.

prompt_templates.title: List available variables
prompt_templates.scenario: Discover what data exists before querying
prompt_templates.prompt: List available statistical variables for geoId/06 and show the top 10 by variable name.

prompt_templates.title: Query county hierarchy
prompt_templates.scenario: Use relation expressions for nested entities
prompt_templates.prompt: Fetch Median_Income_Household for all counties in California using a relation expression with date 2020.

prompt_templates.title: Compare time series
prompt_templates.prompt: Get UnemploymentRate_Person time series for USA and Canada and describe key differences in the trends.

output_examples.input: Show the latest population for California and Texas.
output: Source: Data Commons facet from census.gov

best_practices: Resolve names to DCIDs before running observation queries to avoid ambiguous results
Filter facets to keep data sources consistent across multi-entity comparisons
Check available variables with fetch_available_statistical_variables() before large batch queries
anti_patterns: Querying place names without resolving to DCIDs first, especially for ambiguous names like Springfield
Requesting full time series (date="all") when only the latest value is needed
Mixing facets from different data sources without tracking provenance in your analysis

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude and Codex?
faq.answer: Yes. The prompts and workflows are designed for Claude, Codex, and Claude Code.

faq.question: What are the rate limits?
faq.answer: Limits depend on Data Commons API policies. Check apikeys.datacommons.org for details.

faq.question: Can I use this with pandas?
faq.answer: Yes. Observation responses convert to pandas records using to_observations_as_records().

faq.question: Does it access local files or secrets?
faq.answer: Documentation shows optional CSV export and API key via environment variable DC_API_KEY.

faq.question: What if a query returns no data?
faq.answer: Verify the entity DCIDs, check available variables for that entity, and confirm date validity.

faq.question: How is this different from manual API calls?
faq.answer: It provides structured workflows, entity resolution, and examples while using the official Python client.
